title: Debounce return undefined if func return promise
Please document that `.get`'s `object` argument can be undefined or null

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
So it's clear it's handled and won't throw and it's unnecessary to guard against it. In other words

```
object (Object|undefined|null)
```

I'd extend this to anything that behaves similarly -- like `.pick`, which actually coerces undefined or null to an object -- so you may as well consider in that context.

title: How to apply `convert({ cap: false })` globally?

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Me and my team struggle constantly with capped arguments of callbacks. Converting all the methods all the time seems wrong, IMHO it is better to default to `{ cap: false }` and use `unary(cb)` where it is needed.

I tried to find a way how to override defaults but the [documentation here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/FP-Guide#convert) is not clear to me.

What is the proper way to _uncap_ all lodash/fp methods?

title: suggesting a _.cycle wrapper method #4686

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Consider a button which can sort a list in ascending or descending order.
It would call for a function which will just need an extra parameter which keeps toggling like true/false etc.
Extend this to many other 'states' of the button like 'ascending'/'original'/'descending'.
So this is just a suggestion of a wrapper function which will keep on cycling the parameter list provided by the array in the first initialisation call.

Yet to write the test cases for the suggested methods.

something like 
cyclefunc = _.cycle(func, [false,true])
cyclefunc() // would call func with the last extra argument  as false
cyclefunc() // would call func with the last extra argument  as true
cyclefunc() // would call func with the last extra argument  as false
..
.
And so on.
Also provided a method for changing the cycle direction, and two methods for obtaining the current value and the next value.

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/pull/4686

title: pickBy functionality
body:
Definition: `Creates an object composed of the object properties predicate returns truthy for`.
Let's say I have an object:
`names = [{'firstName': 'santhosh', 'lastName': 'banavath'},
{'firstName': 'Rama', 'lastName': 'Raj'];
result = pickBy(names, {firstName: 'santhosh'})`
Now the expected `result` is `[{'firstName': 'santhosh', 'lastName: 'banavath'}] `.
But the result is `['1':{'firstName': 'santhosh', 'lastName': 'banavath'}] `
Why this behavior is there?
EDIT: It might not have created for the object of the format I mentioned above. Can we have some `property` to do the above operation, instead of iterating through the object and `find`ing the props?

title: [Info] OpenJS Conference & Collab Summit FYIs for Project Communities
body:
Hi LoDash Community 

I've been asked to help make sure that all the OpenJS Foundation project communities are aware that the deadline for our [OpenJS Conference Call for Proposals](https://events.linuxfoundation.org/openjs-world/program/cfp/) has been extended through Feb. 28. Previously, this event was called 'Node + JS Interactive' and it leaned heavily toward Node.js. We're hoping to have a wider range of sessions about all the OpenJS Foundation projects, so we'd love to see presentations about all the foundation's projects!

I also wanted to make sure you're aware of the Collaborator's Summit, an event focused on project maintainers, collaborators & contributors. The goal for the collab summit is to provide opportunities for face-to-face working sessions within a single project or across multiple projects. So if you wanted to get your core team together you could do that, or if you want to have a session for new contributors to your project, or if you wanted to work across multiple OpenJS Foundation projects on issues like accessibility, privacy, security, modules, etc. you could do that too. **If you're interested in securing session space at the collab summit, please ping me here, reach out on slack or twitter, or open an issue on the [/summit](https://github.com/openjs-foundation/summit) repo.** 

The OpenJS World conference is June 23-24 and Collaborator's Summit is June 25-26 in Austin, TX. These are ticketed events, but **members of OpenJS Foundation project communities are eligible for [Travel Fund](https://github.com/openjs-foundation/cross-project-council/blob/master/project-resources/MEMBER_TRAVEL_FUND.md) assistance.** If you have questions or would like to find out more, please chime in on our /summit repo. 

as always, let me know how I can help <3
Jory Burson
OpenJS Foundation Community Manager

title: Why is orderBy number ordering not working correctly?

I am trying to order my table, but this ordering is not working correctly.

Example:
let dataArr = [3257,327,313,315,312,316,317,321,326,302];
I am using => _.orderBy(dataArr, ['number'], ['asc']) => [302,312,313,315,316,317,321,3257,326,327]

Why it isn't return like this [302,312,313,315,316,317,321,326,327,3257]?

How can I figure this problem out?

title: `orderBy` documentation

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
It works (currently) to pass a single string, function, or object as the iteratees, and a single string for 'asc' or 'desc' like so:

```
const sorted = orderBy(unsorted, 'property', 'desc');
```

This is undocumented. Either this shortcut should be documented somehow, or it should fail. I vote documented.

Coincidentally, I'm unsure how using an object as an iteratee would work, but I'd love to learn (without having to read the source, which is what I'm about to do anyway). Adding top level documentation on the ways iteratees work would be nice...Actually, how having poked through the actual code I'm still unclear how that's legal.

title: `_.throttle`'s `wait` not guaranteed in special case

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
I noticed that if you have a throttled callback (secondary) that calls another throttled callback (main) inside a scroll event, and if that secondary throttled callback's `wait` is above certain ms (e.g. 200), and `leading` set to false, then the main callback's `wait` isn't guaranteed.

Sounds like a real edge case, but it may be a common setup for lazyloading scenarios:

```js
const fetchData = _.throttle(() => {}, 1000 );
document.addEventListener("scroll", _.throttle(fetchData, 200, { leading: false }));
```

Repro on [jsfiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/kav5ehmz/4/).

Example waits from a 1000ms throttled callback:

```
731ms
1001ms
1231ms
248ms   <----------
1002ms
235ms   <----------
1001ms
230ms   <----------
1001ms
1237ms
248ms   <----------
1001ms
265ms   <----------
1001ms
```

lodash `4.17.15`

title: _.debounce().flush() fix never made it into produciton

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Hi lodash team,

Having been tracing an issue through my codebase, I discovered that running `flush` on a debounced function doesn't clear any timeouts.

There was a pull request raised a few years ago for this, https://github.com/lodash/lodash/pull/4078, which was merged, however those fixes don't seem to have made it into production, as can be evidenced at:

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4d5fdc492feabf6406dd37e5e843a1261414cbf8/debounce.js (esm version of 4.17.15)

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/15e1557b2a97c8bbee22d873832d90ed3ba50ba7/debounce.js (latest update to debounce.js which is in master at time of writing)

I could re-raise this as a PR but was wondering if there was a reason why the fix never made it in?

title: Iteration in _.every doesn't stopped once predicate returns falsey
body:
Not sure is it bug or it's documentation error, I found issue with _.every function.
It looks like iteration in _.every doesn't stopped once predicate returns falsey.

var z = [1, 2, 0, 5]
_.every(z, (a) => {console.log(a);return a;})
> 1
> 2
> 0
> false

stopped after third iteration.
Code for reproduction:
const b = undefined
_.every([1, b, b.c])
It caught error:
> Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'c' of undefined

But it should not check for b.c if b is falsy, right?

My fault, it's array's initialization specific in js.

title: Undefined fields don't copy with cloneDeep / don't compare with isEqual
body:
Hello, 

I am using lodash to compare if a complex object that represents a form page has changed and in the process I have discovered 2 things:

1. cloneDeep will not copy fields that are undefined to the new object
2. isEqual cares about undefined properties
ex: 
```
let i = { a:undefined, b:'Hello, World!' }
let j = lodash.cloneDeep(i);
console.dir(j); // { b: 'Hello, World!' }
console.log(lodash.isEqual(i,j)); // False because of undefined field
```

Currently i may implement a workaround that strips undefined fields from my source object before comparing, but this is not ideal. In theory cloneDeep should make an exact replica of the object, so
the field that takes the value of undefined should still be coppied.

title: Wording in documentation of collection methods: "objects for"
body: I just looked up `sortBy()` in the documentation and stumbled on the term "objects for..." in the code example: But if this... ``` var users = [ { 'user': 'fred', 'age': 48 }, { 'user': 'barney', 'age': 36 }, { 'user': 'fred', 'age': 40 }, { 'user': 'barney', 'age': 34 } ]; _.sortBy(users, ['user', 'age']); ``` ... creates a sorted array with four objects: `// => [{age: 34, user: "barney"}, {age: 36, user: "barney"}, {age: 40, user: "fred"}, {age: 48, user: "fred"}]` ... Don't you agree that the way it's spelled out the docs is a bit of a puzzle? `// => objects for [['barney', 34], ['barney', 36], ['fred', 40], ['fred', 48]]` I got so confused by the term "objects for", followed by an array of arrays that I considered opening a pull request, but a quick search showed that the same wording is used in the corresponding collection examples (e.g. `filter()`,`orderBy()` or `partition()`), but not in the array examples (`differenceBy()`, `pullAllWith()`), so it seems to be on purpose. Now I'm curious what's the reason for that? Sorry If I misunderstood, or if this is nitpicking, I'm new here... :)

title: What about a conditional caller?
body:
My idea is to have a function that calls a callback when condition is true.
e.g.:
```
when(true, () => console.log('Hello world')) - Hello world
when(false, () => console.log('Hello world')) - Nothing happen
```
If you like the idea, i can work on it :)

title: lodash requires a lot of inodes/file-space
body:
searching thru all projects we deploy using `find /root/of/all/our/projects/sources -xdev -printf '%h\n' | sort | uniq -c | sort -k 1 -n` we see almost uniquely that lodash consumes the most inodes of all dependencies, no matter which project we look at. 
its even the biggest source folder thru all projects (in our php based product).

in our use case we install lodash as a transitiv dependency, which makes it even less appealing.
it is installed via npm.

`node_modules/lodash$ ls -l *.js | wc -l`
shows me that lodash contains contains 631 javascript files.

interesstingly it also contain a `fp` subfolder, which - again - contains 415 javascript files.

I never used lodash and dont know the package structure nor the internals of it.
do you see some room for improvement, so it will contain less files and therefore would consume less inodes?

measured on lodash v4.17.15

title: Importing multiple methods from lodash-es in the same file
Refactor compact function

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

title: add intersperse function

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
intersperse is a function with two parameters, an array and a separator that would be inserted between the elements. [ramda version](https://ramdajs.com/docs/#intersperse)
I think that it's a very useful function, I needed this in my work and I thought I would found it in Lodash. I didn't, but I saw that I'm not the only one who thinks like that. I found a very popular issue about this function. 

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/2339

title: Fix prototype pollution vulnerabilities, fix failing tests
Add ArrayBuffer and SharedArrayBuffer support to isEmpty and size methods

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
This PR add support to ArrayBuffer and SharedArrayBuffer instances and avoid unexpected behaviour to isEmpty and size methods.

Added new test cases

This PR was create based on issue #4570

title: Enable and fix pick tests

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
It flattens the paths and uses `hasPathIn` to support nested / deep paths. This fixes all tests

As a side note, i suggest to not support nested path in `pick` making it smaller. This feature still could be achieved with `pickBy`

title: Enable has methods tests

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Add tests for newly added `hasPath` and `hasPathIn`

Removes tests for deep path for `has` and `hasIn`
Removes sparseString variable since this line `delete sparseString[0];` fails in modern node

Two tests for has / hasIn still fails:

should return `true` for indexes of sparse values
should coerce `path` to a string

Seems that those features were removed purposedly
Should i remove those tests?

title: Handle leading zeros in quote html entity
body:
HTML entities may have [leading zeros](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Character_encodings_in_HTML), so in this case `#39` `#039` both refer to the same character `'`

We noticed this while fixing this issue https://github.com/WordPress/gutenberg/pull/19187

I ran into trouble building and running tests locally, so I'm happy to follow up if there are more detailed instructions elsewhere for running this locally.

### Testing Instructions

- Verify that tests still pass
- No other regressions

To verify this orders correctly, I run the following in the Postman Tests:
```var _ = require('lodash');
const taxonomyList = JSON.parse(responseBody);

pm.test('Get List of All Taxonomies: Response is sorted alphabetically by name', () => {
    const sortedByAlphabeticalOrder = _.orderBy(taxonomyList, ['name'],['asc']);
    pm.expect(taxonomyList).to.eql(sortedByAlphabeticalOrder);
});```

I can verify with my own eyes that the response is correctly ordered, but Lodash incorrectly orders the objects, causing a failing test. F through N are ordered correctly, and A through D are ordered correctly, but the whole thing isn't ordered correctly:

title: "lodash-es" has no exported member "Directory"
body:
For tree-shaking, I use lodash-es. But it doesn't seem to export some members. Currently, I use `groupBy`, but I can't get the type `Directory` of return.  

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29830476/71780759-8c969200-3001-11ea-812c-09ded7f7773f.png)

title: orderBy functions don't work as advertised

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

title: Non coercible objects

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
As of ES5, we can create non coercible objects without `toString` or `valueOf` method.

```js
_.toNumber(Object.create(null));
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/193286/71772187-3107ce00-2f47-11ea-880f-eddc41c970f4.png)

Is this behavior expected ? AFAICT it is not, because the function already tries to handle the `Symbol` primitive type. But, Symbols still have at least `toString` method, which is documented by ES5 `ToNumber` abstract operation. For non coercible objects as described above, I'd expect `_.toNumber` to return `NaN`.

title: _.sortUniq does not work
dropWhile support drop multiple elements
body:
`dropWhile` support drop multiple elements at the same time, don't care from right or left.
may be this way is better than the older version ?

I think It is a useless step, is there any meaning?

![Snipaste_2020-01-01_15-55-47](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41773861/71639318-54b0e700-2caf-11ea-9908-c0ae1aac2191.png)

title: Support for locales in case changing functions

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Javascript now supports locale sensitive case modifiers.  For example:

```
> "iyi".toLocaleUpperCase('tr-TR')
'Y'
```

It would be great if it was possible to leverage this in lodash functions.  For example:

```
> _.capitalize("iyi", 'tr-TR')
'yi'
```

Instead of current more limited behaviour:

```
> _.capitalize("iyi")
'Iyi'
```

Thank you.

title: Ensure in endsWith.js that position parameter will be a number value even if it is input as null
body:
In the endsWith function provided by endsWith.js file, the function only ensure a number value to position when it is undefined, but in the function startsWith, this ensure as well for undefined and null values.

In endsWith.js.
`position = position === undefined ? length : +position`

Supposed to be:
`position = position == null ? length : +position`

While in startsWith.js it is already correctly.
`position = position == null ? 0 : position`

**Also an observation that in startsWith the function does not ensure that if a possible input stirng at position value will be converted to a number**

Then a probably final code supposed to be in startsWith.js:
`position = position == null ? 0 : +position`

title: Ran into an error when packing lodash using rollup
body:
#### Got an error when packing lodash

The error is:

> [!] (rpt2 plugin) TypeError: this.emitFile is not a function
> TypeError: this.emitFile is not a function
>     at emitDeclaration (D:\work\topo\node_modules\rollup-plugin-typescript2\src\index.ts:363:11)
>     at lodash_3 (D:\work\topo\node_modules\rollup-plugin-typescript2\src\index.ts:373:5)
>     at D:\work\topo\node_modules\rollup-plugin-typescript2\node_modules\lodash\lodash.js:4905:15
>     at baseForOwn (D:\work\topo\node_modules\rollup-plugin-typescript2\node_modules\lodash\lodash.js:2990:24)
>     at D:\work\topo\node_modules\rollup-plugin-typescript2\node_modules\lodash\lodash.js:4874:18
>     at forEach (D:\work\topo\node_modules\rollup-plugin-typescript2\node_modules\lodash\lodash.js:9342:14)
>     at Object._.each (D:\work\topo\node_modules\rollup-plugin-typescript2\src\index.ts:371:4)
>     at Object.generateBundle (D:\work\topo\node_modules\rollup-plugin-typescript2\src\index.ts:276:18)
>     at D:\work\topo\node_modules\rollup\dist\rollup.js:16609:25
> 
> npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
> npm ERR! errno 1
> npm ERR! @phoenix/topo-engine@0.1.0 build:aio: `rollup -c config/rollup.config.aio.js`
> npm ERR! Exit status 1


**And there is no node_modules\rollup-plugin-typescript2\src\index.ts file at all.** 


#### Environment 

<!--- describe your environment if it is relevant to the problem --->

#### Versions
- typescript: 3.7.3
- rollup: v1.27.14
- rollup-plugin-typescript2: 0.25.3
- lodash: 4.17.15

#### rollup.config.js

```
// rollup.config.js
// umd
var nodeResolve = require('rollup-plugin-node-resolve');
var commonjs = require('rollup-plugin-commonjs');
var uglify = require('rollup-plugin-uglify');
var json = require('rollup-plugin-json');
var ignore = require('rollup-plugin-ignore');

var common = require('./rollup.js');

var prod = process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production';

module.exports = {
  input: 'src/index.ts',
  output: {
    file: prod ? 'dist/index.aio.min.js' : 'dist/index.aio.js',
    format: 'umd',
    name: common.name,
    banner: common.banner,
  },
  plugins: [
    ignore(['canvas']),
    nodeResolve({
      mainFields: ['module', 'main'],
      extensions: ['.ts', '.js']
    }),
    commonjs({
      include: 'node_modules/**',
    }),
    json({
      include: [
        'node_modules/**/*.json'
      ]
    }),
    common.getCompiler(),
    (prod && uglify())
  ]
};
```

rollup.js

```
var typescript = require('rollup-plugin-typescript2');

var pkg = require('../package.json');

function getCompiler(opt) {
  opt = opt || {
    tsconfigOverride: { compilerOptions : { module: 'ES2015' } }
  }

  return typescript(opt);
}

exports.name = 'topo';
exports.getCompiler = getCompiler;
```

#### tsconfig.json

```
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ESNext",
    "module": "CommonJS",
    "declaration": true,
    "newLine": "LF",
    "esModuleInterop": true
  },
  "include": [
    "src/**/*.ts",
    "test/**/*.ts"
  ]
}
```

title: How about add a _.updateBy func in collection?
I need a cartesian product
body: It would be nice to have a cartesian product in the array algorithm

title: Provides _.isNotEmpty() would be helpful
body: That would be more readability than writing !_.isEmpty(), and in some case when pass _.isEmpty as parameter to a function and expect \_.isEmpty return a opposite value but you can not process in that function, you can't write !\_.isEmpty, it's very inconvenient.

title: Invalid result in findIndex
body:
### Code

```js
const rates = [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ]
const rating = 2
const ratingIndex = _.findIndex(rates, rating]
console.log(ratingIndex)
```

### Result
```
-1
```

### Expected result

```
1
```

title: Add a closest(object, key) method which will return the value of closest key in self or parent object
Added partitionsBy

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body: Have added new function partitionsBy which will help to create multiple partitions based on predicate function.

title: Isn't there a filter that returns Object?
body: `filter` accepts both `Array` and `Object`, but always returns `Array`.
